channel.title: Every Little Thing Minis
channel.description: A fun, bite-sized fact show that tackles your burning questions. Like: Why do we cry? Did cavemen really carry clubs? Why are some people mosquito magnets?

item.title: WTF is Bubblegum Flavor?
item.description: There’s no bubblegum tree in nature — so where does that flavor come from? Confectioners Bob Boutin and Mauricio Bobadilla fill us in on the first-ever bubblegum recipe. Find more ELT episodes here and call any time with your own factual emergency: 833-RING-ELT. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Knockout Sounds: Making a Hollywood Punch Land
item.description: Why do Hollywood wallops sound so punched up? Foley artist and Emmy Award-winning sound editor Joanna Fang shares her punch recipe. Find more ELT episodes here and call any time with your own factual emergency: 833-RING-ELT. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: How to Shake an Earworm
item.description: Why do some songs get stuck in our heads — and is there a way to unstick them? Earworm expert Elizabeth Margulis fills us in. Find more ELT episodes here and call any time with your own factual emergency: 833-RING-ELT. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Dog Show Drama: Why Terriers Are Top-Dog
item.description: Terriers have won nearly half of the Westminster Kennel Club’s Best-in-Show competitions since it began in 1877. How is that pawsible? Dog show judge Laurie Williams tells us what gives terriers a leg-up on the competition. Find more ELT episodes here and call any time with your own factual emergency: 833-RING-ELT. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Do Cats Only Meow at Humans?
item.description: Could Fluffy’s classic catchphrase be for our ears only? Jackson Galaxy, cat behavior expert and host of the TV show “My Cat From Hell,” translates some tabby talk. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: How to Build an Underwater Tunnel
item.description: Have you ever driven through an underwater tunnel and wondered... how did this tunnel get here? Civil engineer Gary Brierley — aka Dr. Mole — explains. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Can You Freeze-Clean Your Pants?
item.description: Should you swap out your front loader for a deep freezer? Cleaning expert Jolie Kerr has answers. Hear more cleaning myths busted on our full-length show. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Why Do We Cry?
item.description: Is there a good reason to let the teardrops roll? Crying researcher and clinical psychologist Ad Vingerhoets has a theory about why we cry. For more on why we well up, try our full-length show. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Stealing the Mona Lisa of Plants
item.description: Listener Carl wants to know: Why would someone lift a water lily from a botanical garden in London? Nick Johnson, horticultural manager of Queen Elizabeth II Botanic Park, Grand Cayman, dishes the dirt on a rare plant heist. Find more ELT episodes here and call any time with your own factual emergency: 833-RING-ELT. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Do I Need to Warm Up My Car?
item.description: In cold weather, should you let your car heat up before taking it for a spin? Auto experts weigh in. Find more ELT episodes here and call any time with your own factual emergency: 833-RING-ELT. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: How Jigsaw Puzzles Are Made
item.description: ELT goes inside a jigsaw puzzle factory to see how puzzles are produced. Thomas Kaeppeler, President of Ravensburger North America, puts the pieces together. Find more ELT episodes here and call any time with your own factual emergency: 833-RING-ELT. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: How to Find a Missing Frog
item.description: Listener Diksha asks: how do we know when an endangered animal species is really gone? Professional frog counter Jamie Voyles has answers. Find more ELT episodes here and call any time with your own factual emergency: 833-RING-ELT. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Why Do Cold Days Make Your Nose Run?
item.description: Why does winter weather turn on your nose faucet? Rhinologist Simon Gane explains why noses start running when the temperature drops. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Space Trash: Is It Coming For Us?
item.description: The Earth is surrounded by a halo of trash — defunct satellites, discarded fuel tanks, one of Elon Musk’s Teslas. Listener Ryan wants to know: Does any of it ever fall down to Earth? ELT talks trash with Ted Muelhaupt, director of the Center for Orbital and Reentry Debris Study. Find more ELT episodes here and call any time with your own factual emergency: 833-RING-ELT. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Is Your Pet a Righty or a Lefty?
item.description: Caller Juanita wants to know if her cats have a preferred paw. Neuroscientist Sebastian Ocklenburg gives us a hand with the answer. Find more ELT episodes here and call any time with your own factual emergency: 833-RING-ELT. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: What’s It Like to Hibernate?
item.description: What do bears do when they hibernate? Sean Farley, a bear researcher at the Alaska Department of Fish and Game, tells ELT what bears are up to during their winter downtime. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: What Is a “Nog”?
item.description: Chef and food writer J. Kenji López-Alt explains how eggnog got its name. You can find his eggnog recipe here. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Do You Only Breathe Through One Nostril?
item.description: Listener Paige heard a rumor: we only breathe through one nostril. Can it be true? ELT gets an answer from someone in the nose — rhinologist Simon Gane. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Hummingbirds Need to Feed
item.description: Caller Makaila needs to know how much to feed the hummingbirds that frequent her father’s feeders. Hummingbird expert Alejandro Rico-Guevara fills us in on these tiny nectar guzzlers, and how they find their fuel. Find more ELT episodes here and call any time with your own factual emergency: 833-RING-ELT. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: How To Tell If Your Plane’s in Trouble
item.description: How can you be sure that turbulent flight doesn’t call for an SOS? Pilots Nick Anderson, of the Airline Pilot Guy podcast, and Sandy Williams glide in with an answer. Find more cockpit confessions with Nick and Sandy here, and call any time with your own factual emergency: 833-RING-ELT. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Much a Doo About Squirrels
item.description: Why isn’t squirrel poop all over the place? Animal behaviorist and pro squirrel watcher Mikel Maria Delgado tells us what it looks like and where to find it. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Why Aren’t Turkey Eggs a Thing?
item.description: Why don’t we gobble turkey eggs like we do chicken eggs? ELT asks egg-sperts Phillip Clauer and Christine Alvarado. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: The Real Pirates of the Caribbean
item.description: Did pirates really have peg legs and hooks? Pirate expert Laura Sook Duncombe delivers the yar or nar on some common pirate tropes. Laura takes on more pirate tales here. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Scrabble’s Scramble to the Top
item.description: Listener Malenia wants to know how her favorite word game came to be. Stefan Fatsis, author of Word Freak, fills in the blanks. For more on how Scrabble scored big, listen to the full episode here. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: How Squirrels Find Their Stash
item.description: The average tree squirrel buries up to 10,000 nuts every fall. How do they keep tabs on their stash? Animal behaviorist Mikel Maria Delgado exposes the secrets of squirrel pantry maintenance.  Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: No Spacesuit, No Space Shoes, Yes Problems
item.description: What would happen to your body if you floated out of your spaceship without a spacesuit? Astrophysicist Paul M. Sutter gives ELT the gory details. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Will That Spider Jump on Me?
item.description: A spider-leary listener wants to know if cold weather means she’s safe from jumping spiders. Linda Rayor, arachnologist at Cornell University, unravels this eight-legged mystery. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: The Finest Ear in the Orchestra?
item.description: How do musicians tune up on a noisy stage? Conductor Rob Kapilow reveals the secret. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Can You Really Feel Someone Else’s Pain?
item.description: Caller Lisa wants to know why her butt hurts whenever she sees someone else get injured. Pain researcher Stuart Derbyshire helps ELT get to the bottom of it. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: How Spies Hide in Plain Sight
item.description: Does that person sitting next to you on the plane REALLY work in IT? ELT learns how to spot a spy in the wild. Guest: Ex-CIA operative Robert Baer. Thanks to caller “anonymous.” Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Bioluminescence: The Glow Below
item.description: More than half of all sea creatures are bioluminescent — but why? We get answers from biologist and ocean researcher Edie Widder, the “Jacques Cousteau of glow.” Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: The Da Vinci Code of Pasta
item.description: Orecchiette n. 8, fusilli n. 16. What do the numbers on pasta boxes mean? Marco Auriti, pasta guy and senior sales manager at De Cecco, reveals the truth. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Should You Dump Your Sponge?
item.description: Should you leave your sponge out to dry . . . permanently? A trio of food safety experts weighs in. Guests: Kathryn Boor, Cornell University; Ian Shaw, University of Canterbury; Renée Goodrich-Schneider, University of Florida. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: What Sparked That Wildfire?
item.description: When there’s a wildfire, how do we figure out what caused it? Fire investigator Paul Steensland tells ELT about the clues that lead him to the cause. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Unlock Your Car With Your Brain
item.description: If you hold your car’s key fob to your chin, can you unlock your car from further away? Jalopnik senior editor Jason Torchinsky sets the record straight about this heady hack. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Armadillos: A Roadside Mystery
item.description: Listener Gwen wants to know why she’s never seen an armadillo alive. Armadillo expert Colleen McDonough has the (unfortunate) answers. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Does Spit Get Out Blood Stains?
item.description: A listener asks: can you clean blood stains with your own saliva? Jolie Kerr, cleaning expert and host of Ask a Clean Person, has answers. For more listener cleanspiracies, check out this episode.  Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: A Little Corn Mystery
item.description: What is baby corn exactly? Carol Miles, a vegetable horticulture expert, solves listener Mary’s tiny lunchtime mystery.  Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Baseball and Organ Music: How’d That Start?
item.description: When did organ music become a fixture at baseball games? Josh Kantor, organist for the Boston Red Sox, explains why the organ hits all the right notes. For more baseball-organ history, including an interview with the legendary organist Nancy Faust, check out our full length episode. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: When Did We Start Wearing Pants?
item.description: While there’s evidence that clothes go back 170,000 years, pants are a relatively recent addition to our wardrobes. Folklorist and historian Adrienne Mayor unravels the surprising story of slacks. For more pants history, try this episode. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Why Are Some People Mosquito Magnets?
item.description: Caller Jenny is itching to know if these tiny bloodsuckers prefer some people more than others. Ecologist and mosquito maestro Don Yee shares some secrets of skeeter attraction. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Will My Brother’s Car Explode?
item.description: Should you turn off your car while you’re pumping gas? Guest: Jason Torchinsky, senior editor at Jalopnik. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Is Brain Freeze Dangerous?
item.description: Listener Molly wants to know whether shotgunning a slushy could cause her physical harm. Blood flow researcher Ole Hensel has answers. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: WTF is Bubblegum Flavor?
item.description: There’s no bubblegum tree in nature — so where does that flavor come from? Confectioners Bob Boutin and Mauricio Bobadilla fill us in on the first-ever bubblegum recipe. More on how bubblegum blew onto the scene here. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Eau de Thrift Store
item.description: ELT gets to the bottom of a familiar aroma with cleaning expert Jolie Kerr of Ask a Clean Person. Thanks to listener Theresa. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Do Airplanes Have Keys?
item.description: Do do you need a key to start an airplane? Pilots Nick Anderson, of the Airline Pilot Guy podcast, and Sandy Williams glide in with an answer. For more cockpit confessions, check out this episode. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Frozen Food: When Does It Get Fishy?
item.description: Listener Max has a fishy question: How long is too long when it comes to frozen fish? Food safety expert Haley Oliver serves up the juicy facts. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: A Shell-Less Snail Tale
item.description: Slugs vs. snails: is there any advantage to sliming along shell-free? Biologist Robert Cowie has been on the snail trail for decades and fills us in on slug life. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Stamps: Who Picks What Sticks?
item.description: How do U.S. postage stamps come to be? ELT explores the secret world of the Citizens’ Stamp Advisory Committee, the group that decides what gets stuck on America’s envelopes. Jessica, a former member, dishes the dirt. More on stamps here. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Who Names Nail Polish?
item.description: How do nail polish colors get names like “Don't Pretzel My Buttons” or “Gouda Gouda Two Shoes”? ELT talks to cuticle queen Suzi Weiss-Fischmann, co-founder and brand ambassador of OPI Products Inc., and author of I’m Not Really a Waitress. For more on nail polish, try our full-length show. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Do Raccoons Wash Their Food?
item.description: Listener Jace wants to know why raccoons wash their food. Raccoon expert Suzanne MacDonald tells us what’s really going on with that signature raccoon rinse. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Should Your Tush Touch the Throne?
item.description: When using a public restroom, should you sit on the seat? A bowlful of biologists, including stall swabber and microbiologist Jack Gilbert, weigh in on the eternal question of whether to sit or hover. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Can Coca-Cola Clean Your Toilet Bowla?
item.description: Cleaning your commode with cola: Handy cleaning hack or baseless cleanspiracy theory? Jolie Kerr, cleaning expert and host of Ask a Clean Person, has the dirt. And listen to Jolie tackle every little stain on our full-length cleanspiracies episode. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Why Do We Cry?
item.description: Is there a good reason to let the teardrops roll? Ad Vingerhoets, crying researcher and clinical psychologist, has a theory about why we cry. For more on why we well up, try our full-length show. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: How Jigsaw Puzzles Are Made
item.description: ELT goes inside a jigsaw puzzle factory to see how puzzles are produced. Thomas Kaeppeler, President of Ravensburger North America, puts the pieces together. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: What’s the Best Seat on the Plane?
item.description: When turbulence hits, which seat has the smoothest ride? Captain Nick Anderson, retired Virgin Atlantic airline pilot and Airline Pilot Guy Show co-host, fills us in. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Why Do Cold Days Make Your Nose Run?
item.description: Why does winter weather turn on your nose faucet? Rhinologist Simon Gane explains why noses start running when the temperature drops. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: How a Hollywood Prop Master Fakes Family Photos
item.description: How do they make the childhood photos that show up in movies and TV shows? Prop master Lynda Reiss dishes on the origin of the faux family photos you see on screen. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: How Popcorn Popped Up in Theaters
item.description: A movie isn’t a movie without the popcorn. But how did those buttery kernels make it to theaters in the first place? Gale Martin, director of the Wyandot Popcorn Museum, cracks the case. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Knockout Sounds: Making a Hollywood Punch Land
item.description: Why do Hollywood wallops sound so punched up? Foley artist and Emmy Award-winning sound editor Joanna Fang shares her punch recipe. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Do FBI Agents Connect the Dots with String?
item.description: Do real-life detectives solve crimes using thumb tacks and red string? Or is this just another Hollywood yarn? Retired FBI agent Jerri Williams solves the evidence-board mystery. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.description: Listener Carl wants to know: Why would someone lift a water lily from a botanical garden in London? item.description: Have you ever driven through an underwater tunnel and wondered ... how did this tunnel get here? Civil engineer Gary Brierley — aka Dr. Mole — explains. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.description: Could Fluffy’s classic catchphrase be for our ears only? Jackson Galaxy, cat behavior expert and host of the TV show “My Cat From Hell,” translates some tabby talk. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Can Ambulances Change Traffic Lights?
item.description: How do-whee-oo-whee-oo they do it? Utah ambulance driver Josh spills the EMTea. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.description: In cold weather, should you let your car heat up before taking it for a spin? Auto experts weigh in. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.description: What do bears do when they hibernate? Sean Farley, a bear researcher at the Alaska Department of Fish and Game, tells ELT what bears are up to during their winter downtime. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: What is a “Nog”?
item.description: Chef and food writer J. Kenji López-Alt explains how eggnog got its name. You can find his eggnog recipe here. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Do Dogs Have Belly Buttons?
item.description: Have you ever given your dog a belly rub and wondered … where’s the b-button? Veterinarian Justine Lee is here with answers. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: How To Shake an Earworm
item.description: Why do some songs get stuck in our heads? And is there a way to unstick them? An earworm expert fills us in. Guest: Elizabeth Margulis, cognitive scientist and musicologist. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices
